_exec_summary.SummaryText:
TO:	RMP Environmental File

FROM:	Mark Hughes, C&D Sr. Manager Env Operations

DATE:	6/22/15

SUBJECT:	Aerosol Can Risk Management Plan
		Church & Dwight Co., Inc
Fostoria, OH Distribution Center

This memorandum includes the following:

¿	RMP Executive Summary Text
¿	Hazard Assessment/Worst Case Scenario Analysis

This memo should be used by each site as the basis for updating their RMP registrations related to aerosol storage, specifically the addition of Batiste Dry Shampoo

Executive Summary

Background

Church & Dwight Co. Inc.(C&D) is engaged in the manufacture and sale of a diversified line of consumer and health care products.  The C&D above designated locations consist of warehouse storage and shipping areas for the full line of C&D consumer products.  Manufacturing operations and/or administrative offices are also present (or nearby).  The local manufacturing operations are not subject to RMP requirements as no RMP chemical thresholds are associated with the manufacturing processes. 

Facility Description

The operations affected by the Risk Management Plan (RMP) involve the receipt and storage of aerosol product in consumer size containers.  Product is received in palletized cases via trailer truck at site loading docks.  The product is moved within the warehouse to a designated aerosol storage location via forklift trucks.  Aerosol product is removed from the warehouse via forklift truck and loaded onto trailers for shipment to customers.  Pallets may be broken down by hand and cases re-palletized to accommodate less than full pallet orders.

Manufacturing operations at the plant do not involve RMP regulated hazardous materials above threshold amounts.  Various hydrocarbons are used as propellants in the finished good aerosol products stored in the warehouse.  Hydrocarbon propellants are defined by the US Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) as hazardous materials.  USEPA enforces regulations designed to minimize the potenti

al for accidental release associated with the handling of hazardous materials.  Additionally, US Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA) enforces accident prevention regulations to protect employees.  The aerosol product propellants are listed as hazardous due to flammability.  The aggregate volume of flammable mixture in the Level II and Level III aerosol can inventory will exceed the RMP threshold.

Accident History

The C&D Distribution Centers have no history of accidental releases associated with the regulated hazardous materials.

Prevention Programs

In accordance with USEPA regulation and results of the hazard assessment, the Church & Dwight Distribution Centers are classified as a Program Level 1 facility.  Program Level 1 facilities are considered by USEPA to present minimal risk to the community.

C&D has developed programs to comply with the required environmental, health and safety standards.  C&D takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals through process management systems and programs which include:
¿	Employee Participation
¿	Process Safety Information
¿	Process Hazard Assessment
¿	Operating Procedures
¿	Operator Training
¿	Mechanical Integrity
¿	Management of Change
¿	Pre-Start up Review
¿	Contractor Safety
¿	Hot Work Permits
¿	Accident Investigation
¿	Compliance Audits

In addition to C&D's management programs, specially designed systems to control, prevent, detect, and mitigate potential accidental releases are also in place.  These include an automatic, early suppression, fast response sprinkler system installed throughout the warehouses.  Aerosol storage racks are segregated by chain link fence and are equipped with in rack sprinkler systems to further mitigate aerosol flammability accidents.  All C&D forklift operators are trained and certified.  The firewater and sprinkler systems are inspected and tested quarterly by an outside independent company. Safety a

nd emergency training of employees is conducted regularly

Emergency Preparedness and Response

C&D has an emergency plan detailing procedures to respond to accidental releases and other emergencies.  The plan is tested on a regular basis through exercises and drills.  The plan is shared with the local Fire Department and county Emergency Services, as appropriate for the warehouse location.  In the event of an emergency affecting the local community, C&D will work closely with the local, county, and state agencies to ensure public safety.  These agencies take the lead in informing the public on appropriate actions in the event of an emergency 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

C&D strives for continuous improvement of its safety programs.  C&D trains our employees to safely perform their assigned tasks.  C&D encourages its employees to suggest improvements or changes that will help minimize the potential for unanticipated failure of programs and equipment, including forklift trucks.  The system and programs are routinely audited, typically by an outside company, to evaluate effectiveness and identify areas for improvement.
 

Hazard Assessment
Aerosol Storage in Warehouse
Church & Dwight Co., Inc. 
Worst Case Scenario (WCS) Analysis

Prepared by: Mark Hughes, CHMM, Sr. Manager Environmental Operations, Church & Dwight Co Inc.
Date: June 22, 2015
1.	BACKGROUND/APPLICABILITY
1.1.	Covered Material
The aerosol storage area at Church & Dwight's Distribution Center (DC) is subject to the requirements of the USEPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) and OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM).
The facility may store, at any one time, greater than 10,000-lbs., in aggregate, of aerosol product. Two primary aerosol products stored include aerosol antiperspirant/deodorant and aerosol dry shampoo.  
1.1.1.	 Aerosol antiperspirant/deodorant
The aerosol antiperspirant/deodorant contains a D-152a/A-17 propellant blend.  D-152a/A-17 propellant blend cont

ains:
Flammable Mixture		% Weight		CAS No.
n-Butane			60-70%			106-97-8
1,1 Difluoroethane		30-40%			75-37-6
Isobutane			<2%			75-28-5
1.1.2.	Aerosol dry shampoo
The aerosol dry shampoo contains a custom propellant blend containing:
Flammable Mixture		% Weight		CAS No.
n-Butane			52-56%			106-97-8
Isobutane			22-26%			75-28-5
Propane			20-24%			74-98-6
n-Butane, difluoroethane, isobutene, and propane are listed as regulated flammable materials in the USEPA's RMP program.  The propellant blend constitutes approximately 61% of the final aerosol antiperspirant/deodorant product by weight and 86.9% of the final aerosol dry shampoo by weight.  The dry shampoo also contains approximately 5% denatured alcohol by weight.  Additionally, each mixture has a flash point below 100 degree F, and is therefore also subject to OSHA's PSM program.
Flammable mixtures are subject to the RMP if there is a regulated flammable substance in the mixture above 1%, and the entire mixture meets the NFPA-4 criteria.  If the mixture meets both these criteria, you must include the total weight of the mixture (not just the regulated substance) in the threshold determination.
NFPA-4 definition is: 
"Material that will rapidly or completely vaporize at atmospheric pressure and normal ambient temperature or that are readily dispersed in air, and that will burn readily."
Based on this definition the referenced mixtures would meet the flammable mixture requirement.
The covered process includes receipt, storage, and distribution of aerosol cans, which contain flammable propellants.

1.2.	Threshold Quantity
The following analysis was completed to determine whether the 10,000 pounds threshold quantity for RMP and PSM would be exceeded.
The contents of each container contain a flammable mixture with greater than 1% of a listed flammable material, and an NFPA rating of 4.  Therefore the entire weight of the mixture inside the can must be used in determining threshold quantity.
1.2.1	Aer

osol antiperspirant/deodorant
The largest single container in the process is a 7 fl oz can (199 max gram fill weight) of product.  Each can contains 61% propellant by weight.  An estimate of the quantity of flammable propellant per pallet of product is:
¿	7 fl oz can = 199 grams/can
¿	199 grams (61%) = 121.4 grams propellant/can
¿	Because >1% - count 199 grams/can
¿	12 cans /case = 2388 grams flammable material/case
¿	125 cases/pallet = 298,500 grams per pallet (or 658 pounds/pallet)
Based on this calculation, 16 pallets would exceed the 10,000-lb threshold for flammables.  It is expected that the DC will have inventory in excess of 16 pallets of applicable aerosol present and is therefore subject to the RMP and PSM requirements.  The aerosol storage cage capacity varies by location.  Maximum storage amounts based on pallet slot storage would be:
Location:		Aerosol Pallet Spaces:		Maximum Inventory (Spaces x 658 lbs/pallet)
Fostoria			124				81,592 pounds
	
1.2.2	Aerosol dry shampoo
The largest single container in the process is a 200 ml can (123 gram max fill weight) of product.  Each can contains 86.9% propellant by weight.  An estimate of the quantity of flammable propellant per pallet of product is:
¿	200 ml can = 123 grams/can
¿	123 grams (86.9%) = 106.9 grams propellant/can
¿	Because >1% - count 123 grams/can
¿	6 cans /case = 738 grams flammable material/case
¿	400 cases/pallet = 295,200 grams per pallet (or 651 pounds/pallet)
Based on this calculation, 16 pallets would exceed the 10,000-lb threshold for flammables.  It is expected that the DC will have inventory in excess of 16 pallets of applicable aerosol present and is therefore subject to the RMP and PSM requirements. The aerosol storage cage capacity varies by location.  Maximum storage amounts based on pallet slot storage would be:
Location:		Aerosol Pallet Spaces:		Maximum Inventory (Spaces x 651 lbs/pallet)
Fostoria			124				80,724 pounds


2.	PROGRAM LEVEL DETERMINATION
The US

EPA RMP program allows for three program levels, each with varying levels of requirements (Program 1, 2, or 3).  Program 3 is the most stringent set of requirements while Program 1 is the least stringent.
In order to qualify for an EPA Program Level 1, the following conditions must be met:
¿	No off-site receptor in WCS hazard zone
¿	No "reportable" accidental releases in the last 5 years
¿	Emergency Response procedures coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning committee/local agencies.
Facilities are considered Program Level 3 facilities if they are subject to OSHA PSM or are a listed North American Industrial Classification System (NAICs) company, unless they satisfy Program 1 criteria.  Program Level 2 facilities are those that do not fit either Program 1 or Program 3 criteria.

3.	WORST CASE SCENARIO ANALYSIS
The WCS is defined as:
"...the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to the defined endpoint"
Based on the USEPA guidance, Risk Management Program for Warehouses (40 CFR Part 68), EPA 550-B-00-009, March 2009:
"For a release from a vessel, you need only consider the largest amount in the vessel. For the specific case of a warehouse, the largest vessels are 350 gallon totes, 55-gallon drums, 10-gallon pails, 150-lb cylinders, and other containers that are small relative to typical vessels in a chemical plant. Therefore, the spillage of the contents of one of these containers constitutes the worst-case scenario, although you may well be able to think of scenarios in which a quantity greater than Q as defined above can be released. Other credible scenarios could involve simultaneous damage to more than one vessel. EPA recommends that you consider multiple-vessel release scenarios, if credible and appropriate, as alternative release scenarios."
Based on this guidance, the WCS can be defined as the loss of containment on a single aerosol can.  This scena

rio, however, may not be considered credible, since if a single can were to catastrophically fail, other cans in the case are also likely to fail.  Therefore two scenarios are assessed 1) failure of a single can and 2) a WCS assumption of the loss of an entire case of cans (i.e. twelve (12) x 7 oz cans or six (6) x 200 ml cans).
The WCS scenarios for the Distribution Center are calculated on the basis of a vapor cloud explosion resulting from the release of flammable propellant.  Scenario 1a and 2a are for Aerosol antiperspirant/deodorant.  Scenario 1b and 2b are for Aerosol dry shampoo.  The following equation used to calculate the distance to endpoint of impact is as provided in the USEPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Warehouses (40 CFR Part 68).

D=0.0081(0.1 x Q x HC/HCTNT)1/3  where:
D=distance to 1 psi overpressure endpoint (miles)
Q=quantity of flammable material present in pounds
HC = Heat of combustion of flammable material
HCTNT = Heat of combustion of trinitrotoluene (TNT) = 4,680 kj/kg






Antiperspirant/Deodorant Aerosols
For the antiperspirant/deodorant aerosol the HC is estimated as follows:
HC Difluoroethane =17,585 kjoules/kilogram (35%)
HC n-butane = 49,700 kjoules/kilogram (65%)
HC propellant blend = 38,802 kjoules/kilogram

Scenario 1a - Single Can (antiperspirant deodorant)
Q = 199 gms = 0.438 pounds
D = 0.0081 (0.1 x 0.438 x 38,802/4,680)1/3 
D=0.006 miles (30.5 feet)

WCS: Scenario 2a - Single case (12 cans antiperspirant deodorant)
Q = 5.26 pounds
D = 0.0081 (0.1 x 5.26 x 38,802/4,680)1/3
D = 0.013 miles (69.54 feet)
WSC Scenario 1a & 2a assumptions:
¿	Loss of containment of a case of aerosol cans in a single vapor cloud
¿	12/cans/case =5.26 pounds (7 fl oz cans assuming entire fill weight of can)
¿	Release quantity = 5.26 pounds
Based on this equation and the above assumptions the distance to 1 psi overpressure endpoint is 69.5 feet.  Generation of a vapor cloud and explosion involving a full case

of cans simultaneously is not considered likely.  A scenario between Scenario 1 (single can) and Scenario 2 (WCS - full case) is the more likely occurrence if a case is damaged in handling (i.e. something less than 69.5 feet to endpoint).  Note this explosion would also occur inside the concrete foundation, steel frame, tilt-up concrete walled building.  The passive controls provided by the building shell would further limit the potential distance to the endpoint.
Dry Shampoo Aerosols
For dry shampoo the finished product aerosol HC was calculated as 39.0 kjoules/gram (39,000 kjoules/kilogram)

Scenario 1b - Single Can (dry shampoo)
Q = 123 gms = 0.271 pounds
D = 0.0081 (0.1 x 0.271 x 39,000/4,680)1/3 
D= 0.005 miles (26.0 feet)

WCS: Scenario 2b - Single case (6 cans dry shampoo)
Q = 1.626 pounds
D = 0.0081 (0.1 x 1.626 x 39,000/4,680)1/3
D = 0.011 miles (57.9 feet)
WSC Scenario 1b & 2b assumptions:
¿	Loss of containment of a case of aerosol cans in a single vapor cloud
¿	6/cans/case =1.626 pounds (123 gram cans assuming entire weight of can)
¿	Release quantity = 1.626 pounds
Based on this equation and the above assumptions the distance to 1 psi overpressure endpoint is 57.9 feet.  Generation of a vapor cloud and explosion involving a full case of cans simultaneously is not considered likely.  A scenario between Scenario 1 (single can) and Scenario 2 (WCS - full case) is the more likely occurrence if a case is damaged in handling (i.e. something less than 57.9 feet to endpoint).  Note this explosion would also occur inside the concrete foundation, steel frame, tilt-up concrete walled building.  The passive controls provided by the building shell would further limit the potential distance to the endpoint.
4.	CONCLUSION
A WCS with an endpoint distance of <70 feet will have no off-site impact and no significant public receptors.  This scenario satisfies the Program 1 criteria for EPA RMP.
